												Ah, Universal Combat.  Somehow I hoped we had seen the last of Derek Smart.  Don't get me wrong, I don't despise the man, but his snarky, combative attitude in the face of the overwhelming evidence regarding his shortcomings as a developer have left me hoping for the day when he retires from public life; that, and I was one of the foolish who purchased Universal Combat when it came out only to discover it was broken and buggy even after several patches and any attempts to challenge this was met by scorn and insult by Derek Smart himself.This is not a good game.  It will not be a good game no matter how many times he changes the name.  It IS a very ambitious game, however.  To his credit, Derek Smart tried to make a game that pushed hardware and design boundaries.  The sad reality is that he failed, but rather than accept this and work with critics to address the problems he chose to attack whatever fanbase he had for pointing out the shortcomings of the game,.  Now it is on steam (for free, no less) and that is supposed to diminish your ability to criticise this product, but for those of us who purchased the game when it first came out it just brings back visions of falling through surfaces, user interfaces better suited to spreadsheet software than a game and terrible, game destroying bugs.I won't address the visuals, which for the time were not bad.  I bought the game originally because of the promise of fps and ship based exploration and combat, and what I ended up with were two halves that never really seemed to fit together or work even on their own.  Attempting to hold the two halves together is an interface that is poorly thought out (see how long it takes you to figure out how quit for a start) and overcomplicated with fields and windows of redundant settings best handled with a single button or accessible from a quick bar.It's unfortunate (but not surprising) to see that time has not changed Derek at all; looking at the comments on steam he continues to attack naysayers with the same eagerness he did on his own forums once, and that is a shame.  I would have hoped that the years had brought him some wisdom about dealing with critics and fans alike, and that rather than insult their intelligence and rebuff their concerns with snarky comments he would have hired a PR representative who has less of an irrational response to criticism.  You will likely play Universal Combat regardless of my review, and I invite you to do so.  You will also discover that the game has some nebulous design decisions and unresolved bugs that will hamper your enjoyment.  Just do not expect your feedback or criticism to be well received or heeded at all by the game's designer as he has great difficulty accepting flaws in his work, though he will gladly take all of your praise.

												So.....this game.Putting aside any personal isssues with Derek Smart (and let's be honest, a lot of people have issues with him), let's try to be as objective as possible in this review...What exactly is UC and does it live up to its claims?It's a 'do anything in space' simulator. You want to command a battlecruiser? Check. You want to be a Marine on a planet shooting stuff? Check. You want to fly from a planet to space and dock with that carrier you see over there? Check.The problem is...well....the problems are...One: Excessive micro management: Why for instance, should the commander of a large ship have to manually set power levels? Why can't....say....the crrew AI do that for you and if you want to then alter it, you can? By default, there isnt't enough power to go around and you have to go in and manually set it. Or, say you want to send....I don't know, four Marines and a tank and a pilot to a planet. You have to tell each individual what to do. There's no group option.Two: HUD issues. The HUD itself isn't intuitive at all, the three MFDs at the bottom of the screen don't easily tell you what they are, the radar is 2d, not 3D and that is confusing as well as you got no clue if the enemy target is above or blow you.Three: Questionable vehicle physics. Why should a shuttle be able to stop on a dime in space? I can understand tanks or ATVs stopping quickly on a planet, that makes sense, however...a shuttle, in space, you cut the power and it instantly stops? Really? Yes, I'm aware it's explained away as some technical stuff but that's an easy and cheap way to get around the issue.So what are the good points then given I've laid out some issues with it?One: You can literally go anywhere and do anything you want to. For instance in a free roaming scenario, I have taken a battlecruiser from Ear to the Moon, landed troops, done exercises, got picked up by the shuttle and flown back, all without cutscenes or scripting.Two: It's seamless once it loads. Yep that's a big, big plus. You want to go from planet to space? Get above a certain height and push a button, then confirm it (again....micro management issues but....), there's a few seconds worth of animation and you're in space. Same for going to a planet.s, get close, it'll ask establish planetfall, say yes,a nd sit back.It's pretty. Oh yes it is, it's some of the most atmospheric graphics in a space game....and you feel as if you can actually go to that nebula, or that planet....or even that base and dock thereYou are not the hero. Okay, this is  astrange one but....most games are all about the player, right? Well, UC, CE isn't. There's an entire universe going on, things happen regardless of you being around or not. You can be in a system and go off for a few days, come back and find that station you were docked at got attacked and changed hands, or there's a war on a planet that broke out while you were going there.However....I personally wouldn't recommend it unless you want to spend a LOT of time reading and learning. It's not a simple pick up and play game in the least, it takes time, dedication and (sadly) figuring things out on your own so you don't have to deal with Derek Smart to enjoy it. Don't get me wrong, once you like it, it's definitely good but I do feel many, many people will be put off by Derek Smart and won't even look at it.If UC was made by somebody else and released on Steam for free, it would get a much, much better reception, I can absolutely say that for certain.Either way, although this has not recommended at  the top, try try it out. Make up your own mind and be prepared for a lot of reading and learning too.

												IMPORTANT TIPIf you jump into this game without reading the manual (you roguish maniac you!) and you’re stuck press either Ctrl+H, Alt+H or Shift+H which will both pause the game and call up the manual or control bindings.Press Ctrl+H to exit the documents.Well…I usually don’t bother writing Steam reviews as I often trust in the overall consensus of those that have already done so (what difference would my 2 cents make?).However this is probably the first time I have found myself in a situation where a game I hold in high regard is otherwise very divided in opinion.I suppose this is the very essence of what it is to be a “niche” game so the first thing I should probably say in this review is that “Universal Combat” (UC) is not for everyone.You will come out of it either loving it or hating it, but very unlikely anything in between.Now much has been said about the need to read the manual before playing and I can appreciate that many gamers nowadays (particularly the younger generation) would consider this requirement (at best) rather quaint in 2015.Indeed with there being so many free games and demos right there at your fingertips, I can see how the investment of time would be a deal breaker for some.As such the best I can do is tell you what 3 aspects of UC appeal to me the most, and should you be intrigued, perhaps you might be willing to preserver though the trials of learning how to play it.* Scale:The 3D environments for both space and planet side are mind-bogglingly vast and I am not aware of any other space sim that can match it (at least outside of an MMO).Capital ships dwarf the size of their occupants (you’ll notice this if you decided to go on a space walk outside your ship) and these ships in turn are tiny compared to the celestial scale of the planets & moons within this universe.If find that UC conveys the enormity of space exceptionally well.It is a very humbling experience to fly to a plant and watch as it fills up the entirety of the view screen.*Planetary landings:Like the space environment, the planet surface is massive (it takes 5 hours in real time to fly around the Earth in a shuttle) and they all have a day/night cycle (some even have weather effects).But what really sets this apart from every other space sim I’ve known is that it lets you land on any moon or planet you come across and explore it in first person (even a gas giant if you don’t mind dying).Any on top of that you can land anywhere you like on the planet’s surface rather than being restricted to predefined zones.However I will admit that the price for this vastness is a great deal of emptiness as the areas outside the city & base zones are pretty much uninhabited.Nevertheless I feel that the procedural generation works well mixing up the terrain features so it’s not like the surface is uniform and everywhere looks the same (the exception of course being barren moonscapes which are supposed to look samey).* A.II’m the kind of guy that is fascinated by A.I in gaming.I find it as much fun observing what an A.I does in various situations as I do playing the game.And Universal Combat has a pretty interesting A.I to observe.Even as you go about your business in the game there is a hell of a lot going on behind the scenes.Trade ships are randomly generated which proceed to each star station along a route buying & selling goods. This will affect the inventory a station has to sell as well as the economy in general.Next you have raiders which are also randomly generated.They will try to attack the aforementioned trade ships and thus their success/failure also affects inventory & economy of the stations.You have :               - Criminals being generated, with police being generated to pursue them.               - Diplomats appearing and assassins dispatched to attack them.               - Colonists & workers headed to uninhabited planets to build cities               - Paramedics looking for the distress signalsAnd of course rival military forces clashing in as chance encounters or as retaliation for some other transgression for which the player never witnessed.While you're docked in a station getting repairs a whole dammed war could be going on outside and given enough time nations that were allies in the beginning of the game can sometimes become enemies just by one incident that the player may have nothing to do with.*Overall:To me Universal Combat is something very special: A vast simulation experiment with a game thrown in.I have been watching this game’s predecessor (the Battlecruiser series) since 1998 and in all that time I have seen nothing which comes close to it in terms of scope & scale.UC is a vast improvement on the old Battlecruiser series in every conceivable way and yet here it is being offered for FREE!?...Unbelievable.However as I said before it is not for everyone.

												Calling this game a "collector's edition" is like calling a used red solo cup a "goblet fit for only a king's mouth". Imagine a big disgusting bag of trash, and then dumping that into a septic tank and taking a long bath in there. That's basically what you're going to get with this abomination of a video game. The following two segments illustrates my first two playthroughs:1. Spawned as the chestical soldier on Earth (elite combat marine with two gigantic chest pads no matter what gender) and some alpha guys that looked like me and were friendly started running up to me shooting. Infantry controls don't work with the "fully supported" xbox controller (but do with vehicles) so I switched to mouse and keyboard for this despite configuring it beforehand for the controller. Aiming with the mouse is a challenge considering the mouse is inverted by default for some reason. I killed one of them, sprinted towards the nearest building, clipped through it and was instantly killed. 2. Spawned as the chestical soldier again and, after slogging through the awful manual, figured out how to enter and drive a SUV with a machine gun ontop around the base. The controls are overly sensitive and incredibily awful. You have to directly target things if your vehicle has a free moving turret, instead of pivoting your mouse or something similar to manuver them around. I tried running people over but they just collect on your hood and get moved around. I shot at a giant yet noiseless patrolling tank a few times, with no reaction, then shot off into the desert by holding the "Down" direction on the left analog stick. The same stick the steering is controlled with, yeah, smart. The main developer, Derek Smart, didn't want anyone to see the truly awful level design outside of this base on Earth that also had truly awful level design, so the base defenses automatically started firing rockets at me as I drove far away from it. I drove over a lake, then into an ocean with my open-air car, and didn't drown even upon exiting. Since I had no idea where to go after spending about 10 minutes or more letting the car drive effortlessly over the oceanfloor, I quit the game and didn't bother looking at the rest of the game until the next day.I have never dealt with a more needlessly complicated system of learning how to do anything. Even tabletop games, which can be fairly complicated, are more readily available to learn than this "turn to page XYZ to even sort of understand what I'm talking about" nonsense. This might fly in the days of Wing Commander and such, but the draw of certain "old school" style game elements just doesn't exist anymore unless you're playing an enthusiast level flight simulator or something. Seriously, page 4 of the tutorial throws every single blinking light at you at once, gives it a dumb 3 letter combination, and says to pause the game and just stare at the UI for awhile. How is that intuitive, or learning anything as you're doing it? By comparison, Elite Dangerous has a similarly complicated UI, with a lot going on in front of you, as well as the need to access the computers on the right and left sides of you at times, but the tutorials are broken down into small scenarios focusing on the basics before anything complicated. Slapping together a couple integrated Word docs that tells you how to play is just lazy, plain and simple. Telling me "go here, fly around the target craft at half speed because I said so, then shoot at it but DON'T KILL IT OR YOU LOSE" is not intuitive. Wouldn't "Collector's Edition" imply you made some improvements to these clearly outdated systems? Or is this part of the code that was only touched in one day, as detailed on Twitter? How does telling us the equivalent of "only the commander really works" in the game description on Steam, then giving us a bad experience in that one single class, tell us that the full upcoming game will not be completely bad as well? I'm wearing headphones as I play this, and the crew randomly babbling things as soon as I jump into a ship makes me think this game is turning me into a schizophrenic. Is this the lost souls of those who played the game calling for me to join them in the underworld?The controls are awful, and I'd like to re-emphasize that here. For example. instead of using the escape key to pause the game and display relevant background information like saving and such, there's 5 million different uses for Alt+*whatever key* instead. There's nothing in the key bindings of this game that screams "intuitive" or "well thought out". In fact, everything about this game's control scheme seems to indicate that it was designed to be played in the Eighth Circle of the underworld from Dante Alighieri's "Divine Comedy", alongside being whipped and having your body immersed in a lake of boiling pitch.There may be some improvements I'm not aware of compared to the base game it originates from, but would you eat a turd if it has pink frosting and sprinkles on it? To me, and likely many others, this is just another failure of many attached to Derek Smart.

So all I see there is "urgent message received."Okay, whatever that urgent message is will have to wait; I need to get down to this planet. Oh look! A button marked "Shuttles." Surely, that will allow me to command my shuttles. Nope. It just opens a branching menu that lets me load the shuttle with... personnel I guess. I'm not sure, since there was nothing selectable anywhere in the tree. Okay, let's go back to the "command" menu tree. Hey look! Shuttles again! Let's launch a shuttle! Tell it to go to that planet!Wait. There's nobody on the shuttle because there's nothing to select in the "shuttles" menu.Then my PC rebooted (which is in no way related to the game).So... In my experience, a tutorial is something that's meant to teach you how to use something. This doesn't do that. Apparently, this is the scenario that's meant to accompany the 90-something-page tutorial novella.Okay. All done. Thanks Derek Smart for making me remember that your games are totally counter-intuitive and inaccessible, even to a guy who lives for complicated games that don't suffer from Monkey Syndrome. Admittedly, this game does not. It suffers from the reverse. Everything in this game seems to defy convention, seemingly for no reason but the defiance of convention.I confess myself pretty disappointed. I was really excited about this game when it was first released in 2004; back when I had the patience to pull it apart and figure it out. Even then I had a hard time with it. I was hoping that a "Collector's Edition" would at least have added a proper tutorial. Pretty disappointed.If you played this game ten years ago and still remember how it works, I can't imagine you'll be disappointed with this new version. It seems like a really cool game; it's just entirely unapproachable. If you don't feel like reading a 90-something-page tutorial, don't bother with this one.It's also nice to see Derek Smart is still totally uninsterested in what anyone thinks of his games. He made it for himself, so why should he care if anybody else can figure it out?

												All right, let's get the obvious out of the way. Derek Smart is an unsufferable (insert your favorite expletive here). That being said, UC is a piece of work of the depth that has only been attempted to be matched in X. Note, I didn't say quality. X is a much more *polished* game. But for sheer variety of things to do, you absolutely cannot beat UC. Are the controls absolutely alien? Sure. Is the manual thick enough to be used as a doorstop for the front doors of Cambridge? You bet. But this was a computer game made for a day when the average user's attention span lasted longer than a game of Flappy Bird, and that speaks volumes more about today's *users* than it does about Derek Smart or any of his games. To anybody who reads this review, I'd like to point something out to you: The users who are panning this game are doing so on one of two things. Derek Smart, of which I will not disagree, and the clunky interface. I don't disagree that the interface is unintuitive, but if you can't figure it out, then the problem is with you, not the game.To edit, now that I've got 15 hours in the game (and roughly thirty hours from before, when I stumbled across a demo version pre-Steam), I stand by my initial statements and say that Elite and Star Citizen (and hell, even X, which is my favorite space sandbox) could stand to learn a lot from this game. There's no game that succeeds at this scale--not even Star Citizen, which is going to restrict you to one ship that you buy, and the rest are behind exponentially-higher paywalls. 												I came from playing Battlecruiser Millenium Gold, and I found that most of the changes to Universal Combat seem to be cosmetic with improved graphics and a slightly modified interface, although there may be more substantial improvements internally as well such as support for modern joysticks. Regardless, it plays essentially the same with only a few keystroke command changes, and in my view it is still a fantastic game. Let me start by stating the obvious: this game is not for everyone, not by a long shot. First off, you need to read the extensive manual. There are just no shortcuts here to be had as you have to invest the time to learn the commands and various interfaces, preferably while having the game running in front of you so you can try out what you learn. And even then you will likely frequently refer back to the manual for the more esoteric stuff. It is a complex game with a steep learning curve, but for a reason, which is that you get to control every facet of your ship and its assets, down to the location of each crew member and their various assignments. You are truly the captain of your ship, and the better you know her the more enjoyment you will get out of the game. On top of that, there are a lot of addtional things you can do like first person piloting of a fighter, shuttle, or rover, or even walk on the surface of a planet and engage in exploration or combat. You can  create concerted attacks on planetary bases by marines on the ground with close air support from fighters and tactical bombing from orbit. You can mine planets to collect valuable minerals for trading in space ports. Or you can just roam the galaxy on a 5 year mission to explore new worlds and new civilizations :) To put it another way, a vivid imagination is a pre-requisite as well as a willingness to immerse yourself in the experience. With time, you will develop a fondness for your crew and an attachment to your ship, the hallmark of a true captain... Now for the detractors out there, this game plays just as advertised. I have yet to experience a serious bug with it and it delivers what it promises. The impression I get from reading many of the negative reviews is that either the reviewers have not taken the time to really learn the game because of its apparent initial complexity or were more suited for different types of games such as Elite Dangerous or its ilk. Universal Combat (and its predecessors) is a monumetal achievement that has no equal in its breadth and capabilities, and for under $10 it is a total steal. Nonetheless, if you prefer to try the game first, then Battlecruiser Millenium Gold is available as freeware and will run perfectly under Win 7 to Win 10 as long as it is set to Win 98 compatibility. And if you are still hesitant, consider reading the Starcarrier SF series from Ian Douglas, as it will give a real feel of what this game is all about.

												I've played all of the battlecrusier games for many years. After the learning curve, the game is very engaging. It is now mid 2016 and I have YET to find a game with this much depth and freedom. This is a game where you have to think in order to suirvive. With all the 4x space games out there now, and all the FPS out there now, this is the one game where you can create your own playstyle. You can go from taking over a starstation to invading a planetary defense system. You can steal enemy craft and even use their own air defense against them. You can be a sniper or have a crew of snipers watch your back as you lead a team of 40 marines into battle. Of course you have close air support knocking down everyting in the sky or any tanks on land that are a threat. And I'm just scratching the surface. You captain a capital ship with up to 8 fighters at your disposal. These fighters increase their skills as they fly missions. Then of course there's shuttles that your AI can take to either drop off mining drones to mine valuable minerals on planets or sent them to tow abandoned or damaged ships including your cap ship. OR you can cripple an enemy ship and send your crew out to tow it to the nearest friendly starport for a nice reward and experience points.  And I'm just scratching the surface.You can leave your command chair and hop in one of your fighters to get in the fray while your flight officer, combat officer, and other staff will continue to pilot the cap ship and keep her on course to her destination. You can have up to 7 AI fighters as your wingmen to help you attack several enemy targets. Or you can have your cap ship engage in multiple targets with powerful beam weapons or fire and forget missles to engage multiple hostile fighters. Or you can command a fleet of cap ships as a supreme commander to completely overwhelm any opposing forces. And I'm just scratching the surface.You can have your cap ship orbit a planet and target a military base below. You can then lauch a space to surface missle to destroy sensitive installations or destroy an entire base... all while you're on the planet watching the mushroom plum from miles away. 												In a nutshell, this is a sandbox, free-roam, STARSHIP simulator.You can do scenarios/missions, if that is your cup of tea.But you can go off and do whatever you want and that freedom the game offers can feel overwhelming.KEEP in mind, this IS AN OLD GAME. Another point: this game is an indie game. No big studio behind it, but as an indie game, like many indie games, it tries to do something original and outside the "generic" genre of games we have to pick from all too often. But this game, specifically, *to-date*, there are very few games that yet to come anywhere close to what it has accomplished.Did I mention this is an old game? It's also a very complicated game. There is a very helpful tutorial and manual.I put a lot of emphasis on the word SIMULATOR. This is not Wing Commander or Freelancer.This is like Jane's F-15 or Falcon 3.0 type overly-complicated simulator games back in the day.Any fan of the prior games will feel at home if they had mastered the controls.The controls take getting used to, but the GUI/mouse interface let's you do most things from the HUD alone now.You can mouse to the shields to raise lower, or partially, or mouse to the MFD displays and toggle various modes if you don't want to use the Hot-Keys. What do you do this in this game? Whatever you want. Pick a "career type" which pretty much establishes what ships you can opt to start out with and where and who your enemies will be; and then launch into space.You micromanage your crew, ship, supplies, but once you get the hang of the controls, you'll appreciate it, there is a lot you can do and a lot of you can keep track of and you might be surprised.Remember in Star Trek, the captain might want to take a shuttle down to a planet to explore and take some bridge crew or officers or whoever with him? YOU CAN DO THAT. You can make personnel report to a shuttle, leave your mothership, fly to some planet way over HERE or THERE, actually fly down to the surface. From there, you can deploy a mining drone, or go take one of your combat vehicles for a spin, or get out and go for a stroll. What to do on the planet? Not much, mining is important and useful. OR, you can go to a city or base and blow it up. The sheer fact you can do this in the game is great. The game doesn't have a fancy polish and I'm sure some will be offput by the execution of some of the features. This an old game, complicated, indie title, so it might feel clunky, shoddy, but it works (no CTDs for me so far). Some people will think going to planets is boring, seems desolate, but I don't know any other game where that is different (take Evochron: Mercenary for example which is quite bare-bones gameplay wise).Once you launch your ship for the first time, you might say: UH OK, now what. This is no X, this is no Elite:Dangerous, but let's you still do a hell of alot more, and as such, the game leaves a lot open to the imagination.PROS:-Familiar controls for those fans of the series-Good ship designs-Lots of things to do, manage crew, track their movements, keep your ship supplied, managed craft-Tons of interface screens, TACOPS lets you play in a sort of RTS style (can't control mouse/seemless zoom style, its a bit different but useful); when in doubt, use the TACOPS feature, it will become your friend.-Land on planets, deploy vehicles, run around like an idiot shooting everything (fun)-Not much to do on planets except mine and shoot everything (lol) or just explore it (cuz it's there!)-Very detailed HUD, MFD's, if you are micromanager and want to know everything, this is it.-Non-NPC spawning mode so newbies can tinker around with the game who otherwise might get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥out the door for the first time-Improved graphics-Space Combat feels streamlined, and its rewarding when your starship goes up against another and you blow them and their support ships to pieces-The HUD display with MFDs you can pull up in FPS mode is awesome, can scan for all sorts of targets. This is the kind of detail I like in games.-I found the AI more responsive in this incarnation. I ejected from my starship and my ship flew off. Went to TACOPS, ordered it me, and to halt. It responded very well. In maybe BC3K v1.0 or 2.0 it might ignore me and fly 1,000,000,000,000,000 km away (my bad for not preparing the AI a/p mode in advance, oops LOL).-You can control just about everything with your mouse through the HUD because it is interactve (so you don't have to rely on hot-keys)-As an older game, graphics performance is good even on lower end computers these days-You'll have lots of great and sometimes stories to tell others about your adventures/events that happen in the game (shut down launch bay power due to intruders on board, assigned marines to guard shuttles, intruder managed to fight them, steal a shuttle with injured marine on board I had to go chase after lol)-IT'S FREE! (*update*: not anymore, but it's low-price, and still worth it).CONS:-Can't re-bind keys-You'll need to study the controls and features, require some patience-Control customization is limited-Controls will take non-veterans of the series sometime to master (not that hard ones you get used to it)-I miss from BC:M being able to walk on the hull of any space object (Star Trek: First Contact-style)-Intruders beaming aboard with shields up still a random nusiance.-BIGGEST GRIPE: Jumping to a target, especially star bases, leaves you too far away, ships fly too slow, and there is no afterburner/turbo boost mode like in the past versions of the game---sorely needed so you don't spend seemlingly forever trying to cover that last stretch like a turtle. Not too bad with enemy ships but mostly with stations. There is a cheat option that lets you go beyond your ship's limits and can be used as a quasi-afterburner mode though.-It shows its age, not really a problem for me, but the planet graphics seemed to be the weak link, had to fly almost touching the ground just to start seeing trees, horizon looks messed up, and didn't see any graphics options to increase view distance-FPS was rather glitchy when near 3D objects, some areas lack polish (not Polish)-This game will fry the brain of anyone with ADD. LOL.Remember, this game is very detailed and complicated. It's sort of like a combination of Evochron:Mercenary and X, but not nearly as polished and feels more complicated, the trade off being you can do a 100x more things. Ultimately, those games still don't come close to the same versatile free-form gameplay or possessing so many options. There is a trade-off and with UC:CE because it tries to do it all and give the players greater control/options.I expect a good number of people will say "this let's you do SO MUCH but I only wish it was implemented better".It is an ACQUIRED TASTE. Like when you have your first beer or wine, or shot of liquor, you're like "ewww, so bitter! why do people even drink this?!" but before you know it, you become a connoisseur.The developer had a great vision and it's too bad some people have expections like this is Call of Duty in Space or some crap. The game is fairly unique, it has been around a long time for that reason and it has a supportive fanbase through the years; the developer still works to support his vision of this franchise and build upon it after all these years, and that is appreciated.

It's 02:38 and we are four jumps deep in to Gammulan space. Already we have taken out two enemy cargo ships and an insurgent light cruiser. But when we ran up against an Engstrom, it was all our Warhammer could do to hold off their fighters and get past their laser system to catch up and make the kill.We have damage on all decks, intruders on board, and a third of our marines are dead with more headed to sick bay. We are attempting to land on a moon for repairs and to lay low for a bit. Don't worry; we'll be back.Universal Combat is something of a trip in to the past, and anyone playing it needs to realize that. When I first played this way-back-when, it was probably the most absolutely complicated game I had ever attempted to play, and 14-year-old me really liked having to figure everything out as I went along and really learn how to play this thing. And frankly, that's where the satisfaction is. Universal Combat hails from a time when games really didn't tell you how good you were doing. There were no 'atta-boys. The satisfaction came from realizing that you had figured the game out and were getting good at it.I suggest giving this a try and playing it for at least 6 hours before deciding if you like it or not. I personally enjoy the challenge of not just moment-to-moment ship management, but of the long term planning you can really get in to when determining either a brief patrol of border space or an extended campaign in to enemy territory. What spare parts should I take? Where should I deploy mining drones for resupply? Where can I park for repairs? And I do mean park for repairs; if you make poor choices and take damage, you realistically could be down for hours. It's brutal. But coming through several of those limp-home-and-pray adventures is what builds the narrative in your head and really helps you get in to the game, I think. I might not be able to follow my marine security detail around while they hunt down saboteurs, but damn if I don't stare at the PERSCAN screen and yell obscenities at them anyways. It's not polished, it's not perfect. You'll have complaints. But if you give it a real chance and keep an open mind, you'll probably never forget playing it, and you'll have a totally different sort of fun with it than you do with Planetside 2 or Smite. And hopefully you'll stick around for Derek's next project, because I have a feeling it should be pretty cool.

												An underrated indie gem. Derek Smart deserves credit for sticking to his guns, and sticking with this game. Universal Combat isn't pretty, easy or intuitive. But it's still an unmatched capital ship simulator with an unforgiving '90s-style attitude.This game will not hold your hand (tip: read the manual) or tuck you into bed at night. It's definitely not for everybody. It's about outer space and it wants to kill you. It's a sandbox with the complexity of hardcore naval sims such as Silent Hunter.It's about logistics, space battles, crew management, reactor meltdowns and nuking cities from orbit. You will be boarded, ransacked and the perpetrators will escape in a stolen shuttlecraft.Your ship will be set adrift while on fire.Why Universal Combat MattersI didn't discover this game until recently. I've known about Smart since the early 2000s, but dismissed him and didn't give him a chance. He was a joke, a crank, his games were bad. That's what I thought, but in reality I didn't understand him. Now I do ... I think.Smart is foremost an engineer, as this game reflects an engineer's mindset. It's about spaceships, but it's really about complex systems, taking things apart and figuring out how they work. This has its downsides: Engineers are not celebrated for their empathy and they don't make for great artists. But engineers do make great systems.

												This game brings back memories.  Yes, it had a troubled release back in 1996 but blame Gametek for that one.  There's not another game in existence that creates this kind of immersive world in a fully modeled futuristic starship along with planetary surfaces, planetary bases, space stations, and moons.  I can land my ship, or take a shuttle, or beam down the surface for a leisurely stroll across a beach or I can drop in with my Marines for a full blown assault on an enemy base. Or I can just hang out on my bridge and "nuke the site from orbit."  And that's the endless possibilities of free roam.  I haven't touched on the scripted campaign which can be tough as nails but incredibly fun and rewarding.  The massive space stations that will blow you to pieces with a burst of their weapons, the fact that I can hop into a fighter and duke it out while my capital ship supports me.  Oh, there's also fleet command and control, trading, capturing starstations, ship to ship combat, trading, mining, powerful artifacts that can turn your ship from kick-butt to kick♥♥♥♥♥♥and-take-names-without-breaking-a-sweat style. This game is complex and it requires some time investment to learn the concepts and the systems.  If it helps, think of this game as "Falcon 4.0" in space only you aren't flying an F-16 but a half mile long starship with fighters, shuttles, marines, landing craft.  There's a plethora of resources from a well-written manual, tutorial videos, and in game help but make no mistake this is a game that will require some learning but its oh so rewarding.  Don't let my steam playtime fool you, I started playing this game in 1998 with the release of BC3K 2.0 and I can safely say that in the past 17 years no other game has come close to doing what this one does.  If you want to be in command of a futuristic starship (don't think Captain Kirk....this ain't no wimpy Enterprise...more like William Adama) with entire fleets to command and stations to blow up and planetary surfaces to fight on then this game is for you.

If you get intruders on board they'll run off with your cargo.. and shuttles/fighters!-Use perscan when you have marines on board, and assign them accordingly. ALways PREP FOR COMBAT.-Upgrade your REACTOR before you upgrade your engine.-Buy at GALCOM and sell at MAJORIS-Deploy mining drones on seperate moons/planets. Not only does this make it easier for you to keep track of which shuttle is picking up which drone, but also you get a wider variety of minerals. (Sell at Majoris)-If you see static on your HUD.. CLOAK AND RUN. If you don't have cloak then EMD AND RUN. It's a cloaked enemy ship, possibly fleet, and if they're cloaking it means their AI is probably higher than your crews AI so they WILL get on board or open fire if you don't get out of there. It'll be days, possibly even weeks, before your crew has the skills to take on such an enemy.-Don't attack starbases without a fleet or without friendly nearby ships also attacking.-Regularly stock up on RADINE, PLUTONIUM, NUTRIPAKS-Keep your turrets at 60%, guns at 30% and shields at 25% to conserve energy. Raise shields when enemy is around. Guns should be fine unless you're outnumbered, they're pretty powerful even at those %'s.-Regularly send out a shuttle with the "Cargosweep" order. They'll sweep your current & surrounding sectors for ejected cargo pods full of goodies. Be careful though, some pods are booby trapped.-Beam Resnig down onto the most volanic, vile planet you can find.-Keep playing. This is not a fast-paced game. To see any real progress it will take days, not hours.

												I really like this game and highly recommend it to anyone who likes old school PC games and simulations. If you ever dreamed of being in command of a space battleship then you should give this game a try. I spent many nights flying through the galaxy role playing as Captain Julian Augustus, Battlecruiser Commander and I can't wait to get a free weekend or three to give it another go. This game is very complex and and takes a while to learn to play it. This game is originally from a time when PC games came in a box and included a detailed and lengthy manual. These manuals were often a treat and included background information, cool artwork, a written tutorial, list of commands, etc. I miss those types of manuals. The tutorial is a PDF file that you print out or read on a tablet while you play through the tutorial scenarios.  I'd recommend doing that. And print out the command reference as well or keep it open on a tablet. The main thing to understand is that this game is deliberately complex. It is designed for someone who wants to feel like they are commanding a real battleship. To get the most out of this game you have to learn to play it and you have to use your imagination and really get into the role playing and the simulation. If you treat it like an arcade style game you're going to get frustrated.
